descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will be taught by Prof. Michael Wairungu.

This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of beginning Swahili. The course equips learners with the necessary listening, speaking, reading and writing skills so as to understand basic Swahili. We shall learn about the history of Swahili language, its place in East Africa, and discuss how to interact with Swahili speakers in culturally appropriate ways. Through a combination of lectures, lab sessions and performance of cultural and communicative activities, learners will gain an understanding of basic Swahili grammatical structures and cultural insights of the people of East Africa. No prior knowledge of Swahili is required to enroll in this course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: On completion of the course, students should be able to appreciate basic cultural practices of the Swahili speaking people. They should also comprehend basic Swahili, and use simple grammatical constructions to perform day-to-day linguistic functions such as greetings, self-introduction and interpersonal conversations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be based on the following six major areas of language use: attendance and participation (10%), homework (15%), weekly vocab quizzes (15%), two sit-in quizzes (20%), Mid-term exam (20%) and final exam (20%). Each learner who attends at least three-language/conversation table meetings will be awarded an extra-credit of 3 points to be added to the final grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
(these texts also apply to the Winter and Spring "Swahili I" courses):

1) Hinnebusch, Thomas J. and Sarah Mirza. Kiswahili: Msingi wa Kusema, Kusoma na Kuandika, 2nd Ed. Lenham, Maryland: University Press of America, 1998
2) Swahili Exercises: A Workbook for First Year Students by Lioba Moshi.
3) Swahili-English, English-Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.
